title: Wetherspoon hits out at higher living wage
text:
Wetherspoon hits out at higher living wage Joel Lewin and Nathalie Thomas IHG agrees $938m Hong Kong hotel sale 
The chairman of JD Wetherspoon hit out at the government’s plans to introduce a higher national living wage, warning that it brought “considerable uncertainty” to the pub industry. 
Shares in the UK pub chain fell 8.4 per cent on Wednesday to a 12-month low after it highlighted a number of cost pressures that threatened to erode its earnings. 
Wetherspoon’s operating margin fell to 7 per cent in the 11 weeks to July 12 from 8.3 per cent during the same period last year. Its full-year operating margin is expected to be just 7.4 per cent. 
“The recent government announcement regarding the ‘living wage’ adds considerable uncertainty to future financial projections in the pub industry,” said Tim Martin, chairman. 
The company admitted that pre-tax profit this year was “unlikely to be higher than last year”. 
In the budget, chancellor George Osborne said that he would increase the minimum wage for over-25s to £7.20 from £6.70 in April, and to £9 by 2020. 
The pressure of rising wages compounded the threat posed by cheap supermarket alcohol sales, which have been cannibalising the earnings of pubs for several years, Mr Martin said. 
“The average price of a pint in a supermarket is less than £1 and we estimate staff costs to be around 10 per cent or 10p. In contrast, a pint in a pub costs around £3 and staff costs are about 25 per cent or 75p. Increased labour costs therefore affect pubs with far greater force than supermarkets.” 
He added that this disadvantage was “compounded by a huge VAT and business rates disparity between pubs and supermarkets”. 
8.4% 
Fall in JD Wetherspoon share price, to 706p, on Wednesday 
Shares in Wetherspoon have fallen 20 per cent since 2011. They closed down 65p to 706p on Wednesday. 
Some analysts were still optimistic, though, about the group’s prospects. 
“The ‘living wage’ will increase costs but it will also put more money in the pockets of would-be JD Wetherspoon customers,” said Mark Brumby, analyst at Langton Capital. 
“The group is likely to be outperforming its competitors — and particularly those without access to the funds to invest — and longer term, it should draw clear from the pack,” he added. Related Topics
